html:
1.27.19  3:41 pm   Why don't you capitalize your name or the letter 'i' when you refer to yourself?

here

      Does it have anything to do with e.e cummings? 


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201706190013

6.19.17  12:13 am   hallo! I wanted to ask you about I's, as I don't run into many other people who do not follow the capitalization guidelines just as they are given. I capitalize names as a measure of respect, and I consider I to be a name (your name for yourself when you are conveying yourself to someone else) but with how often I's turn up in text, it can feel self centered to capitalize it so often. do you think I should consider changing my policy?

     there are many reasons why i like to leave the i lowercase. 1. it seems a bit more humble 2. it seems more casual 3. it is less pretentious 4. capital i looks exactly like a different letter 5. a lower case i is much more personal and has more personality because it has an eye
original_html:

html:
1.27.19  8:33 am   hey, same person from 1.26.19  7:59 am , how do i then figure out what key that main melody is then when the notes fit both Dmaj and Amaj scales? And even that mixolydian thing you mentioned? 


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201901260759

1.26.19  7:59 am   hi bill, it's the same person asking about the harmonies and intervals of that melody and i've been experimenting some more and i found another strange thing. I tried some different harmonies over that melody i already mentioned (with notes F# B A C#) and I found that D G F# A over that melody also works in a cool way?

     yea that would be almost like you are in the key of D

      How come when G isn't in the A major scale at all

     it's in what you might call the A "cool" major scale, the ancient greek name for that being "mixolydian." which also happens to be the exact same notes as the regular key of D, if you rotate the room around

      (i think G is a diminished 7 in that scale, correct me if im wrong)?

     flat7

      Is there any rhyme or reason of why some things apparently work and some don't?

     scientists will never quite figure it out but they will keep trying

      Like some broken rules get you an even cooler thing but if you break some other rule it gets you a bad thing? Or is my knowledge of the rules so bad that i'm not actually breaking any just discovering new rules i didnt even know about? 

     it is essentially the same rules that make you like someone's personality, or enjoy a story, or find beauty in patterns of soap scum
